All NHS provider bodies registered with the Care Quality Commission (CQC) must comply with Regulation 20, Duty of Candour. The purpose of this policy is to provide clarity to staff on their obligations with regards to Being Open and the Duty of Candour.

Mid and South Essex University Hospitals Group promote a culture of openness and truthfulness when things go wrong, a prerequisite for improving the safety of patients and the quality of healthcare services provided.
Being Open involves:

Promptly acknowledging, apologising and explaining what happened to patients, and/or their carers when things go wrong as a result of their healthcare treatment or attending the Trust as an inpatient or outpatient;

Conducting a thorough investigation within the agreed timeframe into the patient safety incident and reassuring patients, their families and their carers that lessons learnt will help prevent recurrence;
Providing support to those involved to cope with the physical and psychological consequences of what happened.
This policy applies to all Trust staff working within the three Trusts in Mid and South Essex (MSE).

This policy supports the Policy for the management of incidents and serious incidents, the Procedure for the reporting and management of incidents and serious incidents and the Learning from Deaths policy.
The policy applies to those incidents categorised as having resulted in moderate harm or above, including death or where prolonged psychological harm has resulted.

A higher level response is required in these circumstances. The patient safety team should be notified immediately in accordance with the policy for the management of incidents and serious incidents requiring

Definitions

table_items.text: The process of acknowledging, apologising and investigating when a patient safety incident occurs. It is a process rather than a one off event.
All healthcare professionals have a duty of candour – this is a professional responsibility to be honest when things go wrong
Any unintended or unexpected incident that could have, or did, lead to harm for one or more patients receiving NHS funded healthcare. This term includes incidents, complaints or claims.
Enabling concerns and complaints to be raised and disclosed freely without fear, and for questions to be answered.
Allowing information about the truth about performance and outcomes to be shared with staff, patients, the public and regulators

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
Chief Executive has overall responsibility for:
Governance within the Trust including ensuring a framework is in place to support openness between healthcare professionals and patients and/or their carers following a patient safety incident and;

Actively championing the Being Open and Duty of Candour process by demonstrating a commitment to openness, honesty and transparency in all aspects of patient care and fostering a learning and just culture that discourages the attribution of blame;
This responsibility is delegated to the Chief Nurse.
Site Medical Directors / Directors of Nursing have delegated responsibility for Governance within the Trust and are the nominated Director Leads for championing and implementing this policy.
Chair of the Quality Committee will act as the Non-Executive lead for Being Open and will champion the principles of Being Open.
Associate Director Patient Safety is responsible for ensuring that the Patient Safety Team support the being open process and for providing advice and support to staff involved.
Divisional Directors / Lead Clinician / Associate Directors of Nursing / Heads of Nursing / Heads of Midwifery / Department Leads
Responsible for:

Identifying the most appropriate member of staff to meet with a patient and/or their relative / carer following a patient safety incident normally a Consultant, Associate Director of Nursing, Head of Nursing / Head of Midwifery / Matron or Ward Sister, but always a person with appropriate seniority and/or experience;
Providing feedback and support to staff involved in a patient safety incident or in the Being Open process.
Complaints and Claims and Legal Teams

Responsible for ensuring that Complaints and Claims processes support a culture of Being Open providing support to staff involved in a patient safety incident which has or may result in a complaint and/or claim being made.
All Staff
All staff are expected to adhere to this policy and to promote an open and fair culture;
Staff should be aware of their responsibility to acknowledge and report incidents as soon as they are identified;
Where patients and or their carers inform staff that a patient safety incident has occurred, they should take this seriously and act with compassion and understanding;

Junior staff or those in training may be involved in the Being Open process described below but should not lead the process unless the incident is assessed as a low harm event and the senior healthcare professional responsible for care is present for support.
Being Open and Duty of Candour process

Being Open is a process that should commence whenever a patient safety incident is detected. It encompasses the prevention of further harm, reporting and investigation to identify why the incident occurred and how recurrence can be prevented and the communication with the patient, their family or carer.

data.text: Immediate Actions
Incident Recognition
The Being Open process begins with the recognition that a patient has suffered harm or has died as a result of a patient safety incident. A patient safety incident may be identified by a:
Member of staff at the time of the incident;
Member of staff retrospectively when an unexpected outcome is detected;
Patient, their family or carer who expresses concern or dissatisfaction with the patient's healthcare at the time of the incident or retrospectively for example through a complaint;
Medical records review
Structured Judgement Review (mortality review).
Clinical Care

When a patient has been harmed, the immediate priority is to ensure that prompt and appropriate clinical care is initiated to prevent further harm. Where additional treatment is required, this should be discussed with the patient if possible or with their carer or next of kin, if the patient is unable to participate. Consent must be sought in accordance with the Trust's Consent Policy.
Reporting

6.3.1 Whether a patient safety incident is recognised by a member of staff, patients, their family or carer as it occurs or as a result of a complaint or legal claim, the incident should be reported as soon as it has been identified on the incident management system in accordance with the Procedure for the Management of Incidents and Serious Incidents.
6.3.2 Where a patient, their family or carer informs clinical staff directly of an incident, these concerns should be taken seriously, investigated and treated with compassion.

6.3.3 Where an incident is identified as having occurred in another organisation, the Trust's Associate Director Patient Safety should ensure the organisation where the incident occurred are notified to establish whether the:
Incident has already been recognised;
Being open process has commenced;
An Incident investigation is underway.
Criminal or unsafe acts

6.4.1 Patient safety incidents are almost always unintentional. However if at any stage following an incident it is determined that harm may have been the result of a criminal or intentional unsafe act, the Associate Director Patient Safety, Director of Nursing, Medical Director, Chief Medical Officer and Chief Nurse must be informed immediately;
6.4.2 Reference to NHSI's A Just Culture Guide may offer assistance in determining the appropriate action by managers.
(Refer to Appendix 6)
Preliminary Team Discussion
Prior to the initial meeting with the patient, their family or carer, the appropriate members of the multidisciplinary team should meet as soon as possible after the incident to establish:
The clinical and other facts known at the time;
The level of response required as determined by the severity of the harm caused (refer to table 1) and, if indicated, the need to alert the Patient Safety Team of a potential serious incident;
The lead member of staff for communicating with the patient, their family and carers;
The timing of the discussion;
The need for any patient support at this stage (this might include the use of a facilitator or a patient advocate);
Immediate support needs of the healthcare staff involved.
If there is disagreement amongst the multidisciplinary group about any of the facts, communication about these issues should be deferred until after the investigation is completed.

The identified lead, will normally be the most senior person responsible for the patient's care; the patient's consultant. They should have expertise in the type of incident that has occurred, good interpersonal skills, knowledge of the facts relevant to the incident and be available for ongoing communication. The identified person should then provide the patient, their family or carer(s) with:
A meaningful and compassionate apology for the harm caused - an apology is not an admission of liability;
An explanation of what happened without any admission of liability;
An explanation about the investigation process and what will happen next.

The lead should be supported by at least one other senior member of staff such as the DivisionalDirector / Lead Clinician / Heads of Nursing / Heads of Midwifery / Associate Directors of Nursing / Department Lead or other member of the healthcare team experienced in the Being Open process. Consideration should be given to the communication skills of the team members to ensure clear, effective and sympathetic discussions take place.
Where the lead is not known to the patient, a member of staff such as the patient's ‘named nurse' should be present to offer support.

Where a member of the healthcare team is directly responsible for the error that resulted in harm, they may or may not wish to participate in the Being Open discussion. Each case should be considered individually balancing the needs of the patient, their family or carers with those of the healthcare professional concerned. If the healthcare professional wishes to attend in order to offer a personal apology, they should be supported by their colleagues throughout the meeting. If the patient, their family or carer expresses a preference that the healthcare professional should not attend the meeting, this should be respected and a written apology should be offered.

The patient, their family or carer should be asked who they would like to be present and if during the discussion it clear they would prefer to speak to a different healthcare professional, those wishes should be respected. The involvement of a facilitator or patient advocate may be considered. Where there are information or communication support needs, the appropriate support such as the use of translators should be provided. Refer to Trust translation and accessible information policies. Where there are language difficulties a translator should be provided.

The meeting should be held as soon as possible after the incident is detected. Normally this will be within 10 days. The patient's, their family's or carer's circumstances including the patient's preference, patient's clinical and emotional condition and availability of the patient's family or carer and of key staff such as a translator or advocate should be taken into account. The patient should be offered a choice of times. Once arranged, the meeting should not be cancelled other than in exceptional circumstances.

The meeting should be held in a suitable area, ideally this should be away from the place where the incident occurred, within the limits of the patient's clinical needs, and there should be no opportunity for interruptions. In some cases it may be appropriate to hold the meeting in the patient's own home.
Meetings should be attended by key Trust representatives only, so as not to overwhelm the patient, carer or advocate.
Initial Being Open Discussion with the Patient, their Family or
Carer

The relevant person must be informed as soon as reasonably practicable after the incident has been identified. Normally this will be within 10 days of the incident being identified. The patient, their family or carer should receive an acknowledgment of what happened and a sincere apology for the distress and harm caused as a result of the incident on behalf of the team. Expressing regret is not an admission of liability.
All staff should be introduced with their roles identified.
The patient, their family or carer should be informed of any known facts relating to the incident and that they will be fully informed of the outcome of the investigation when this is available.
During the discussion there should be neither speculation as to what happened nor blame attributed. There should be no denial of responsibility nor conflicting information from different individuals.

The understanding by patient, their family or carer of what happened, should be taken into account together with any questions they have. Questions and concerns should be considered, documented and taken seriously, they may form part of the serious incident investigation.

Clear, straightforward language should be used avoiding the use of jargon or acronyms. Where there are language issues, a translator should be used. In all cases understanding should be confirmed at the end of the discussion with an opportunity to ask questions.

An explanation should be given of what will happen next, both in terms of any short or long term effects and treatment plan(s), and the investigation process, and contact details provided for a named person who will be available for future communications.

Assurance should be given that the patient will continue to be treated according to their clinical needs and that the incident will not affect their access to treatment. If the patient, their family or carer wishes that their healthcare needs be taken over by another team or organisation, this should be respected.

Sources of support and counselling should be offered as appropriate. This might include help from other hospital departments, charities and voluntary organisations (refer to appendix 2). Information about the patient should not normally be disclosed to third parties without consent.

The patient and / or their carer should be made aware of the complaints procedure and offered assistance should they wish to make a complaint. Their questions could also be answered as part of the serious incident investigation.
Documentation of the initial discussion
8.11.1 A summary of the initial being open discussion should be documented within the incident management system.

8.11.2 A complete and accurate record of the initial discussion must be entered in the patient's notes. The Trust Initial Meeting Record template (MR1) may be used to support this documentation (refer to Appendix 3). The record should be signed and dated and include:
A brief description of the information given including noting an apology was given, the known facts, any clinical after-effects, treatment plans, sources of support, contact details of lead;
The preferred frequency and mode of communication;
What key questions the patient, their family or carer would like answered in the course of the investigation;
Key action points with identified leads and deadlines;
Patient's, their family's or carer's reaction;
What will happen next.

Dependant on the severity of the outcome for the patient and their preferences or those of the patient's family or the patient's carers, the information given, key points, action points, assigned responsibilities and deadlines should be confirmed in writing. An initial Duty of Candour letter should be sent to the patient or relevant person as soon as reasonably practicable. The letter should then be retained within the incident management system.
Particular Patient Circumstances

The approach to Being Open may need to be modified according to a patient's personal circumstances including where a child is involved or there is cognitive impairment. If it is determined that a patient lacks mental capacity, and has no relative(s) or carer(s), the designated Independent Mental Capacity Advocate should be involved in the Being Open process (Mental Capacity Act 2005). Refer to the Safeguarding Adults Policy and mental capacity act policies.

To ensure open and effective communication, the Trust should identify the patient's practical and emotional needs including the names of people who can provide assistance and support and with whom the patient agrees information may be shared.

The extract from the NPSA Being Open Framework (2009) on managing communication in particular patient circumstances is provided in appendix 1. This includes additional information for cases of untimely, unexpected or unexplained death, and suspected unnatural deaths, which must all be reported to the Coroner.
Patient Information/Support:

9.4.1 Patients and/or their carers may need considerable practical and emotional help and support after experiencing a patient safety incident. It is therefore important to discuss their individual needs with the patient and/or their carers. Support may also be provided by the following:
The patient's family;
Social Workers;
Religious Representatives;
Patient Advice and Liaison Services (PALS);
Independent Complaints Advocacy Service (ICAS).
9.4.2 Where the patient needs long term emotional support, advice should be provided on how to gain access to appropriate counselling services.

9.4.3 The Trust will provide information on services offered by all the support agencies (refer to Appendix 2), including contact details that can give emotional support, help the patient identify the issues of concern, support them at meetings with staff and provide information about appropriate community services.
Follow-up Discussions

Depending on the circumstances of the incident and the timescales identified, there may be more than one follow up meeting and patients, their families and carers must be kept informed of progress in accordance with the arrangements made at the initial meeting.
In order to ensure effective communication:
The follow up discussion should occur at the earliest practical opportunity
Consideration should be given to the timing and place of the meeting, based on both the patient's health and personal circumstances;
Consideration should be given to the location of the meeting e.g. the patient's home;
Feedback should be given on progress to date and information provided on the investigation process;
There should be no speculation or attribution of blame. Similarly, the healthcare professional must not criticise or comment on matters outside of their own experience;
The patient / relevant person should be offered an opportunity to discuss the situation with another relevant professional where appropriate;

A written record of the discussion should be kept and shared with the patient / relevant person. This record should also be attached to the incident; management system where this is possible and relevant fields completed.
All queries should be responded to appropriately;
If completing the process at this point, the patient / relevant person should be asked if they are satisfied with the investigation and a note of this made in the patient's records.
Process Completion
After an investigation has been completed the findings should be shared and feedback provided to the patient, their family or their carer including:
A repeated apology for the harm suffered and any shortcomings in the delivery of care that led to the patient safety incident;
The chronology of clinical and other relevant facts;
Details of the patient and/or their carer's concerns and complaints;
A summary of the factors that contributed to the incident;
Information of what has been and will be done to avoid recurrence of the incident and how the implementation and effectiveness of these improvements will be monitored;
Ongoing clinical management if appropriate.
The patient, their family and carer should be asked if they are satisfied with the investigation and a note of their response made. They should also be made aware of the Trust's complaints process.
Documentation (retention)
11.3.1 Documentation associated with all stages of the investigation and analysis should be stored and recorded on the incident management system.

11.3.2 Files relating to the investigation of serious incidents should be retained in electronic and/or hard copy format in a secure location for a minimum of 30 years, as per Records Management NHS Code Of Practice Part 2 (2nd Edition) policy Department of Health/ Digital Information Policy (2009).
11.3.3 The incident management system is the designated storage system for documentation associated with this policy.

11.3.4 A complete and accurate record of all discussions must be entered in the patient's notes. The Trust Feedback Record template (MR2) may be used for this purpose where appropriate (refer to appendix 4). This record should be signed and dated and include:
A brief summary of the information given;
The patient's, their family's or carer's reaction;
Any remaining questions the patient, their family or carer raised and the responses given;
Offers of assistance;
What will happen next.
11.3.5 Key points, action points, assigned responsibilities and deadlines should be confirmed in writing.
11.3.6 For investigations into events graded as moderate harm or above, each stage of the Being open/Duty of Candour process must be recorded (refer to Appendix 5).
11.3.7 Overdue actions associated with incidents are identified monthly and reported to the appropriate Governance meetings.
Continuity of Care

Where a patient safety incident has resulted in harm, the patient, their family or carer should be informed of the on-going clinical management plan. If appropriate, these details should be included in the discharge summary provided to designated individuals such as the GP, district nursing service or other healthcare organisation responsible for any on-going care needs.

The patient, their family or carer should be reassured that they will continue to be treated according to their clinical needs, even in circumstances where there is a dispute between them and the healthcare team. They should also be informed they have the right to continue their treatment elsewhere if they have lost confidence in the healthcare team involved in the patient safety incident.
External Communication
GP, Community Care Service Providers or other NHS Organisations
Wherever possible, it is advisable to send a brief communication to the patient's GP before discharge, describing what happened so that they may offer their support.

When the patient is transferred or discharged from the Trust, a discharge summary should be forwarded to the GP or appropriate community care provider summarising the nature of the incident and continuing care and treatment plans.
Support for staff involved in the investigation of a patient safety incident

Any member of staff involved in the investigation of an adverse incident can obtain advice and support from their line manager or the patient safety team. If a member of staff is particularly distressed or requires professional support, this can be obtained via their line manager from the Occupational Health Department. Each
case is assessed on an individual basis, and support such as counselling may be offered.
Exceptions
There are some types of incident and circumstances where initial duty of candour will not be achieved or is inappropriate. In such circumstances the final Duty of Candour will be met in writing.

In some cases it may not be possible to meet the duty of candour or it is deemed inappropriate. For example, where, despite reasonable steps being taken, a relative cannot be traced. In such circumstances this will documented and a waiver agreed with the Trust's Commissioners.

Wherever staff are following the process for open communication, full consideration should be given to the patient's and the relevant staff members' privacy and dignity. Identifiable details relating to patients or staff involved in a patient safety incident will be considered confidential at all times and shared on a need to know basis only in accordance with the group's Confidentiality Policy and Sharing Patient Information Policy and in line with the Data Protection Act Principle 3.
Where lessons learnt are shared for the purpose of improving service provision, the details must be anonymised.
The group is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to Appendix 7)
All new staff receive Being Open awareness training.
Investigating Officer training includes the Duty of candour requirements. There is also a MSE Duty of Candour  training module available on the Trust's training platform.
This policy will be disseminated via the Trust intranet.
It is the responsibility of all staff to make sure they have read this policy and are aware of the Duty of Candour principles.
This policy will be updated three yearly or sooner in response to local or national guidance or initiatives.
The Trust is committed to implementing guidance on Being Open and this policy is consistent with the following:
National Patient Safety Agency (NPSA), Patient Safety Alert: Being open (2009). NPSA, Being open: Communicating patient safety incidents with patients, their families and carers (2009)
NPSA, Seven Steps to Patient Safety (2004) Involve and communicate with patients and the public'
National Health Service Resolution (NHSR), Apologies and explanations. Letter to chief executives and finance directors (2009)
General Medical Council (GMC), Good Medical Practice (2001)
Nursing and Midwifery Council (NMC), The Code: Standards of conduct, performance and ethics for nurses and midwives, (2008).

Appendix 1 NPSA, Being open: Communicating patient safety incidents with patients, their families and carers (2009).
Particular patient circumstances

The Trust's approach to Being Open may need to be modified according to the patient's personal circumstances. The following gives guidance on how to manage different categories of patient circumstances.

When a patient safety incident has resulted in a patient's death it is even more crucial that communication is sensitive, empathic and open. It is important to consider the emotional state of bereaved relatives or carers and to involve them in deciding when it is appropriate to discuss what has happened. The patient's family and carers will probably need information on the processes that will be followed to identify the cause(s) of death. They will also need emotional support. Establishing open channels of communication may also allow the family and carers to indicate if they need bereavement counselling or assistance at any stage.

Usually, the Being Open discussion and any investigation occur before the coroner's inquest. But in certain circumstances the healthcare organisation may consider it appropriate to wait for the coroner's inquest before holding the Being Open discussion with the patient's family and carers. The coroner's report on post-mortem findings is a key source of information that will help to complete the picture of incidents leading up to the patient's death. In any event an apology should be issued as soon as possible after the patient's death, together with an explanation that the coroner's process has been initiated and a realistic timeframe of when the family and carers will be provided with more information.

The legal age of maturity for giving consent to treatment is 16. It is the age at which a young person acquires the full rights to make decisions about their own treatment and their right to confidentiality becomes vested in them rather than their parents or guardians. However, it is still considered good practice to encourage competent children to involve their families in decision making.

The courts have stated that younger children who understand fully what is involved in the proposed procedure can also give consent. This is sometimes known as the Fraser guidelines. Where a child is judged to have the cognitive ability and the emotional maturity to understand the information provided, he/she should be involved directly in the Being Open process after a patient safety incident.

The opportunity for parents to be involved should still be provided unless the child expresses a wish for them not to be present. Where children are deemed not to have sufficient maturity or ability to understand, consideration needs to be given to whether information is provided to the parents alone or in the presence of the child. In these instances the parents' views on the issue should be sought.

Being Open for patients with mental health issues should follow normal procedures, unless the patient also has cognitive impairment (see below). The only circumstances in which it is appropriate to withhold patient safety incident information from a mentally ill patient is when advised to do so by a consultant psychiatrist who feels it would cause adverse psychological harm to the patient. However, such circumstances are rare and a second opinion (by another consultant psychiatrist) would be needed to justify withholding information from the patient.
Apart from in exceptional circumstances, it is never appropriate to discuss patient safety incident information with a carer or relative without the express permission of the patient.

Some individuals have conditions that limit their ability to understand what is happening to them. They may have authorised a person to act on their behalf by an enduring Power of Attorney. In these cases steps must be taken to ensure this extends to decision making and to the medical care and treatment of the patient.

The Being Open discussion would be conducted with the holder of the power of attorney. Where there is no such person, the clinicians may act in the patient's best interest in deciding who the appropriate person is to discuss incident information with, regarding the welfare of the patient as a whole and not simply their medical interests. However, the patient with a cognitive impairment should, where possible, be involved directly in communications about what has happened.
An advocate with appropriate skills should be available to the patient to assist in the communication process. See section 5 below.

Where a patient has difficulties in expressing their opinion verbally, an assessment should be made about whether they are also cognitively impaired (see section 4 above). If the patient is not cognitively impaired they should be supported in the Being Open process by alternative communication methods (i.e., given the opportunity to write questions down). An advocate, agreed on in consultation with the patient, should be appointed. Appropriate advocates may include carers, family or friends of the patient. The advocate should assist the patient during the Being Open process, focusing on ensuring that the patient's views are considered and discussed.

The need for translation and advocacy services, and consideration of special cultural needs (such as for patients from cultures that make it difficult for a woman to talk to a male about intimate issues), must be taken into account when planning to discuss patient safety incident information. It would be worthwhile to obtain advice from an advocate or translator before the meeting on the most sensitive way to discuss the information. ‘Unofficial translators' and/or the patient's family or friends must not be used as they may distort information by editing what is communicated.

A number of patients will have particular communication difficulties, such as a hearing impairment. Plans for the meeting should fully consider these needs. Knowing how to enable or enhance communications with a patient is essential to facilitating an effective Being Open process. This involves focusing on the needs of individuals and their families and being personally thoughtful and respectful.

Sometimes, despite the best efforts of healthcare staff or others, the relationship between the patient and/or their carers and the healthcare professional breaks down. They may not accept the information provided or may not wish to participate in the Being Open process. In this case the following strategies may assist:
deal with the issue as soon as it emerges;
where the patient agrees, ensure their carers are involved in discussions from the beginning;
ensure the patient has access to support services;

where the senior health professional is not aware of the relationship difficulties, provide mechanisms for communicating information, such as the patient expressing their concerns to other members of the clinical team;

offer the patient, their family and their carers another contact person with whom they may feel more comfortable. This could be another member of the team or the individual with overall responsibility for clinical risk management;
use a mutually acceptable mediator to help identify the issues between the healthcare organisation and the patient, and to look for a mutually agreeable solution;
ensure the patient, their family and their carers are fully aware of the formal complaints process;
write a comprehensive list of the points that the patient, their family and their carers disagree with and reassure them you will follow up these issues.

A national charity providing support to both bereaved families and the professionals who supporting them.
24 hour helpline for children and young people who need to talk about any problem.

National charity providing information to anyone affected by a death. Exists to promote the well- being of bereaved people and to enable anyone bereaved by death to understand their grief and cope with their loss. Provides counselling and support and offers information, advice, education and training services

Hope Again is the youth website of Cruse Bereavement Care. It is a safe place, where young people who are facing grief can share their stories with others. Hope again provides somewhere to turn to when someone dies.
Information about how people normally grieve after a loss and places to get help
24 hour confidential emotional support for anyone in a crisis.
Stillbirth and Neonatal Death Society (SANDS) Helpline: 020 7436 5881 http://www.uk-sands.org/

A national charity, established by bereaved parents which aims to support anyone affected by the death of a baby. It works in partnership with health professionals to improve the quality of care and services offered to bereaved families and to promote research and changes in practice that could help to reduce the loss of babies' lives.
A helpline providing confidential emotional support to children, young adults and adults
